verses.text: Do not rely on your wealth, and do not say, 'I have enough.'
verses.comment: The warning here recalls how trusting in riches leads people away from dependence on God. See also Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 6:24 about serving God rather than wealth.
verses.sectionHeader: Warnings Against Presumption and Delay in Repentance

verses.text: Do not follow your strength to walk in the desires of your heart.
verses.comment: Here, the text warns against letting personal desire override obedience to God's law, a principle reflected throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Do not say, 'Who can overpower me?' For the Lord will surely punish you.
verses.comment: Boasting in one's own power ignores the sovereignty of God, echoing the teaching against pride in James 4:6.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I have sinned, and nothing bad happened to me,' for the Lord is patient.
verses.comment: God’s patience should not be mistaken for indifference to sin. This is a key theme in both Old and New Testament teachings on repentance and judgment.

verses.text: Do not be so confident in forgiveness that you keep adding sin upon sin.
verses.comment: This verse cautions against presuming on God’s mercy, a theme also addressed by Paul regarding grace—not a license to sin.

verses.text: Do not say, 'His mercy is great, He will forgive the abundance of my sins.' For both mercy and wrath come from Him, and His anger rests on sinners.
verses.comment: The balance of mercy and justice in God’s character is emphasized here. Spiritual interpretation suggests true repentance and conversion is essential.

verses.text: Do not delay to turn to the Lord, and do not put off repentance from day to day.
verses.comment: Prompt repentance is urged, reflecting the urgency seen in Christ’s call to conversion. There is a spiritual sense here of being always ready and watchful.

verses.text: Do not depend on dishonest wealth, for it will not benefit you on the day of calamity.
verses.comment: Sirach warns against relying on ill-gotten gain, echoing wisdom traditions (e.g., Proverbs 10:2), teaching that such wealth is ultimately futile in times of judgment or crisis.

verses.text: Do not winnow in every wind, or follow every path.
verses.comment: The proverb cautions against inconsistency and fickleness—comparable to chaff blown by the wind—urging readers to avoid shifting principles for personal advantage (see James 1:6).

verses.text: Stand firm for what you know, and let your speech be consistent.
verses.comment: Sirach praises integrity and steadfastness, emphasizing that a wise person's words should reflect inner conviction rather than opportunism (cf. Matthew 5:37).

verses.text: Be quick to hear, but deliberate in answering.
verses.comment: The counsel to listen quickly but answer thoughtfully reflects the wisdom tradition's high valuation of careful speech (cf. James 1:19), highlighting prudence as a virtue.

verses.text: If you know what to say, answer your neighbor; but if not, put your hand over your mouth.
verses.comment: Advocating restraint, the sage advises speaking only with knowledge, recognizing that ignorance can be masked more easily by silence than by misguided speech (cf. Proverbs 17:28).

verses.text: Honor and dishonor come from speaking, and the tongue of mortals may be their downfall.
verses.comment: This verse stresses the power of speech for both honor and ruin, warning that one's tongue can be a cause of downfall or social disgrace (cf. James 3:5-6).

verses.text: Do not be called double-tongued and do not lay traps with your tongue; for shame comes to the thief, and severe condemnation to the double-tongued.
verses.comment: The double-tongued—hypocrites or deceivers—are strongly condemned, aligning the harm of deceitful speech with theft and warning of severe judgment (cf. Proverbs 6:16-19).

verses.text: In great and small matters cause no harm.
verses.comment: Sirach enjoins a universal ethic of non-maleficence, emphasizing that one should avoid causing harm in matters both great and small (cf. Romans 12:17-18).
